channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: 3,000 Civilians Escape Besieged City of Mariupol
item.description: A Red Cross convoy will try again to reach the city on Saturday. President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine accused Russians of laying land mines as they retreat.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents who escaped Mariupol and nearby towns arrived in the town of Zaporizhzhia on Friday.

item.title: Shaken at First, Many Russians Now Rally Behind Putin’s Invasion
item.description: Polls and interviews show many Russians now accept the Kremlin’s assertion that their country is under siege from the West. Opponents are leaving the country or keeping quiet.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: A Moscow theater building with the letter Z, signifying support for the war.

item.title: War in Ukraine Compounds Hunger in East Africa
item.description: The conflict has driven up the cost of food in a region that depends heavily on crops from Russia and Ukraine and is facing what could be its worst drought in four decades.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: People in Somalia who fled drought-stricken areas arrive at a makeshift camp on the outskirts of the capital, Mogadishu, in February. The drought has left nearly a third of the country’s population hungry.

item.title: Pope Apologizes to Indigenous People of Canada
item.description: Pope Francis also promised to visit Canada as part of a process of healing and reconciliation over the church’s involvement in an abusive system of residential schools.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the children whose remains were discovered near the Kamloops Indian Residential School in British Columbia.

item.title: Costa Rica’s Close Election Tests Women’s Rights
item.description: In Costa Rica’s runoff on Sunday, voters will decide between a candidate found to have sexually harassed junior employees at the World Bank and a former president once accused of corruption.
item.dc:creator: David Bolaños and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Rodrigo Chaves, a leading candidate for the presidency of Costa Rica, in the capital, San José, in February.

item.title: Living With Gusto Despite a Rare, Fatal Disease, and Hunting for Answers
item.description: At 26, Sammy Basso is believed to be the oldest person with the disease Progeria. And now he’s researching it, hoping to find a treatment and the secrets of aging.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sammy Basso training with his runners club, a group of friends and fans who run marathons to support progeria awareness.

item.title: Covid Outbreak at Shanghai Hospital Exposes Risks to China’s Seniors
item.description: Coronavirus infections have spread at an elder care facility in Shanghai. Workers said deaths are increasing and resources dwindling.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Amy Chang Chien and Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Residents filling out online forms in order to be tested for coronavirus in Shanghai last month.

item.title: Turkey Moves Closer to Ending Khashoggi Murder Trial Without Conclusion
item.description: Turkey’s justice minister said he would agree to transfer the trial to Saudi Arabia, effectively ending a case that rights groups hoped could offer a measure of justice.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: A candlelight vigil for Jamal Khashoggi in front of the Saudi Embassy in Washington in 2019.

item.title: Europe Asks China Not to Aid Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: A first E.U.-China summit in two years was overshadowed by Ukraine and China’s alliance with Moscow and produced few results.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: The E.U.-China summit shown in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: New Zealand Protesters Seeded Marijuana Plants on Parliament Grounds
item.description: New Zealand officials say anti-vaccination protesters seeded cannabis during a three-week occupation.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mike Scott/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Anti-vaccine protesters left trash and other surprises outside Parliament in Wellington, New Zealand, this month.

item.title: Prosecutor Asks Turkey to Turn Khashoggi Murder Case Over to Saudis
item.description: All 26 suspects accused in the killing of Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident Saudi journalist, in Istanbul in 2018 are Saudi nationals.
item.dc:creator: Safak Timur
item.media:description: A symbolic funeral prayer for the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul in November 2018, about a month after he was killed.

item.title: A Nation of Spy-Catchers: Fear of Saboteurs Has Ukrainians on Edge
item.description: There are checkpoints, hotlines and apps for reporting suspicious activities. Ukrainians worry about saboteurs mixing among them, sowing mistrust and spreading misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers at a checkpoint on the outskirts of Lviv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Imran Khan Defiantly Refuses to Resign as Pakistan’s Leader
item.description: Prime Minister Khan, who faces the prospect of being removed from office by Parliament, accused the United States of mounting a conspiracy to topple his government.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Prime Minister Imran Khan addressed the nation on TV on Thursday, vowing not to resign and claiming to be the victim of a U.S. conspiracy.

item.title: In Hungary, Viktor Orban Remakes an Election to His Liking
item.description: The populist prime minister, a hero to many American conservatives, has changed voting rules and legalized ‘voter tourism’ as he stands for re-election
item.dc:creator: Matt Apuzzo and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary during the Fidesz party’s congress in Budapest, in November.

item.title: U.S. Will Help Transfer Soviet-Made Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: The transfer, a response to a request from Ukraine’s president, will mark the first time the Biden administration has helped send tanks in the five-week-old war.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Soviet-made tanks will allow Ukraine to conduct long-range artillery strikes on Russian targets in the eastern Donbas region, an American official said.

item.title: Two New Jersey High Schools Reinstate Mask Mandates After Covid Outbreak
item.description: New coronavirus cases have led to the resumption, if temporarily, of some mitigation strategies.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.category: South Brunswick High School (Monmouth Junction, NJ)
item.media:description: South Brunswick High School in central New Jersey reinstated its mask mandate on Friday.

item.title: Zelensky Calls for Popular Disobedience, in Both Ukraine and Russia
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine threatened retribution for people who collaborate with occupying forces and accused retreating Russians of planting mines and even booby-trapping corpses.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Ukrainian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine in Kyiv on Friday, before a meeting with Roberta Metsola, the president of the E.U. Parliament.

item.title: Spike in Violence Poses Test for Israel’s Fragile Government
item.description: A rash of terrorist attacks has spawned criticism of the government from the left and right, and for opposite reasons. But the coalition’s diversity has constrained its options.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Right-wing activists protesting against Prime Minister Naftali Bennett in Tel Aviv this week.

item.title: Charles G. Boyd, Air Force General and Former P.O.W., Dies at 83
item.description: He began his 36-year career in the military as a fighter pilot and was the only prisoner of war in the Vietnam conflict to become a four-star general.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Budi Tek, 65, Dies; His Fortune Built a Vast Trove of Asian Art
item.description: He was one of the world’s top collectors, and his immense Yuz Museum in Shanghai helped establish the region’s bustling art scene.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Budi Tek in 2012. A Chinese-Indonesian billionaire art collector, he specialized in what he called mega-art, like the one behind him: Adel Abdessemed’s “Telle Mer, Tel Fils” (“Like Mother, Like Son”), consisting of three full-scale airplanes intertwined.

item.title: Russia’s Aggression Prompts Calls to Rethink U.S. Uranium Imports
item.description: The war in Ukraine has highlighted the risks of U.S. dependence on Russia for the fuel needed for nuclear energy, creating new challenges for the industry.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague

item.title: U.N. Says Yemen’s Warring Parties Have Agreed to 2-Month Truce
item.description: The agreement comes after a significant escalation in recent weeks that saw Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthi rebels claim several attacks.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: The aftermath of airstrikes by the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen’s capital, Sanaa, last month.

item.title: Fires, Then Floods: Risk of Deadly Climate Combination Rises
item.description: A new study found that the dangerous pairing of disasters may become more common in the American West as rains trigger runaway surges of mud and debris in areas damaged by wildfire.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: People helped a neighbor retrieve belongings from a home damaged in a mudslide in Salinas, Calif., in January 2021.

item.title: Evacuation of Mariupol Falters as Red Cross Team Is Turned Back
item.description: At least one group of private vehicles left the battered city, but a larger effort failed when unsafe conditions prevented a Red Cross team from reaching the city to escort an evacuation convoy.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: Some evacuees from Mariupol and other front line cities have continued to arrive in Zaporizhzhia, but a general evacuation of the besieged city stalled on Friday once again.

item.title: Researchers Find Another Clue in the Dyatlov Pass Mystery
item.description: The mystery of nine hikers who died in Russia has baffled people for more than 60 years. The authors of a recent paper think they’ve found another clue.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Battleground Nevada
item.description: The state will help determine Senate control in this year’s midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters at Paradise Recreation Center on Election Day in Las Vegas, in 2020.

item.title: Nuclear Agency Looks Into Reports of Radiation Poisoning at Chernobyl
item.description: Russian soldiers left the decommissioned nuclear plant and a nearby city after five weeks of occupation.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Solar panels next to the structure containing the damaged fourth reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in northern Ukraine last July.

item.title: As Gas Prices Soar, Biden’s Climate Ambitions Sputter
item.description: Rising costs at the pump, war in Ukraine, an emboldened fossil fuel industry and stalled legislation have imperiled President Biden’s climate agenda.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:description: President Biden’s aides acknowledge that the legislative centerpiece of his climate agenda is unlikely to become law, and other pieces of his agenda may fall in the Supreme Court.

item.title: Ukrainian Olympian Does His Part Against Russian Invasion
item.description: Vladyslav Heraskevych, a skeleton competitor from Ukraine, gathers supplies and uses the team van to deliver them to Kyiv as he waits to be called for military duty.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vladyslav Heraskevych, a skeleton Olympian from Ukraine, on a supply run in Kyiv.

item.title: Midnight Oil Brings Australia Home
item.description: Australia has had its fair share of music that made it big overseas. But why do some bands succeed internationally while others do not? And does that even matter?
item.dc:creator: Besha Rodell
item.media:description: Peter Garrett, center, and Midnight Oil performing in Melbourne, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Fighting rages on in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers and emergency service workers carried bodies in Irpin, Ukraine, after fighting yesterday.

item.title: E.P.A. Decides Against Limiting Perchlorate in Drinking Water
item.description: Drinking water for as many as 16 million Americans may be contaminated with perchlorate, a chemical that can harm the development of fetuses and children.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Disappointing environmental advocates, the Environmental Protection Agency has chosen not to impose limits on perchlorate, a chemical linked to a measurable decrease in I.Q. in newborns.

item.title: More Mixed Signals From Russia as Ukraine War Enters Sixth Week
item.description: Moscow appeared to adjust its position on humanitarian access to Mariupol, but there was little evidence to support Russian claims of a military pullback near Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Anton Troianovski and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A military funeral for three Ukranian soldiers in Lviv on Thursday.

item.title: Russia’s War Lacks a Battlefield Commander, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Poor logistics and flagging morale have plagued a disjointed military campaign in Ukraine, according to American officials and independent analysts.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: An image provided by the Russian government showed Sergei K. Shoigu, the Russian defense minister, center, and Gen. Valery Gerasimov, to his left, holding a meeting with ministry leaders in March.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Biden Releases Oil Reserves
item.description: The war in Ukraine is snarling global energy supply.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters from the Odin Unit returning from battle as emergency services and Ukrainian soldiers carrying out the bodies of soldiers and civilians under the Irpin Bridge in Irpin, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Syrian Mercenaries Deploy to Russia en Route to Ukrainian Battlefields
item.description: A first contingent has arrived in Russia for military training including members of a Syrian unit that worked with Russian officers in Syria, backing President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Hwaida Saad and Asmaa al-Omar
item.media:description: Syrian soldiers being trained by a Russian officer in Syria in 2019.

item.title: A European bank forecasts that Ukraine’s economic output will contract by 20 percent in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency crews responded to a fire at an oil terminal hit by Russian missiles in Lviv earlier this month.

item.title: Many U.S. teens report emotional and physical abuse by parents during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: The data underscores the protective role that schools can play in the lives of young people, especially those grappling with racism or gender identity, experts said.

item.title: What Does Ukraine Mean When it Asks For ‘Security Guarantees’?
item.description: Ukraine’s request for other countries to guarantee its future security as a condition for making concessions to Moscow is circulating among European diplomats. But analysts say such a demand faces huge obstacles.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces manned a security checkpoint in Kyiv earlier this month.

item.title: Macron Goes on Defensive Over Use of McKinsey and Other Consultants
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s opponents have criticized the French government for paying at least a billion dollars last year to private consulting firms.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron, center looking up, during a campaign visit to Fouras, western France, on Thursday. There is about a week left before the country’s presidential election.

item.title: Why Putin name-checked J.K. Rowling
item.description: Putin has used scaremongering about gender and sexual orientation to support his authoritarian agenda. Right-wing politicians around the world are following the same playbook.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia attending a meeting with young award-winning culture professionals via videoconference in Moscow, on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Levels New Sanctions on Russian Tech Companies
item.description: Some of the new sanctions focus on organizations that supply or support Russia’s defense sector.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow last month. The U.S. Treasury Department issued new sanctions on Thursday aimed at interfering with Russia’s efforts to evade existing sanctions.

item.title: Ireland’s Last ‘Magdalene Laundry’ Will Become a Memorial
item.description: A compound in Dublin where unmarried mothers and other unwanted women were incarcerated to work in abject conditions had been earmarked as a site for a budget hotel.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: The derelict Gloucester Street Laundry in Dublin, the last of Ireland’s infamous “Magdalene laundries,” in 2018.

item.title: NATO Sees Little Evidence That Russian Troops Are Pulling Back From Kyiv
item.description: “Russia has repeatedly lied about its intentions,” NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg said of Moscow’s pledge to pull back from Kyiv. “So we can only judge Russia on its actions, not on its words.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Remnants of a shell that landed in Irpin, outside of Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, during fighting for the suburb earlier this month.

item.title: Students and Teachers in Europe Grapple With the War in Ukraine
item.description: As many in Europe have grappled with the shock of facing a war on their doorstep, teachers say they are facing tough questions posed about the conflict by worried children.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tara Harmer speaking to her class during a debate on the war in Ukraine at Heron Way Primary School in Horsham, England, on March 21.

item.title: Kenya’s Supreme Court Rejects President’s Plan to Amend Constitution
item.description: Civil society groups had criticized the proposal as an attempt to expand presidential power and strengthen the elite’s grip on national politics.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya in New York in 2018.

item.title: Putin’s Approval Ratings Soar Amid Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: Eighty-three percent of Russians said they approved of Mr. Putin’s actions, up from 69 percent in January, according to an independent pollster in Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin at a meeting in the Kremlin in Moscow on Wednesday, in a photo distributed by state-run media.

item.title: Myanmar Junta Holding 10,000 Political Prisoners
item.description: Most are held in deplorable conditions and face certain conviction at trial. Rights groups say the Southeast Asian nation now has the worst human rights conditions in the region.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Clearing a path before prisoners were released from Insein Prison in Yangon, Myanmar, in February.

item.title: Moscow Calls US Intelligence on Putin’s Military Advice a ‘Complete Misunderstanding’
item.description: The Kremlin spokesman also played down the prospect of an April meeting between Presidents Vladimir V. Putin and Volodymyr Zelensky.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin with his Defense Minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, center, in Moscow in 2020.

item.title: Two Covid Problems
item.description: The U.S. may soon run out of Covid money. That’s not the only problem.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vaccination clinic in Hagerstown, Md., in February.

item.title: Was North Korea’s New ICBM Test Faked? Not Entirely.
item.description: South Korea says Kim Jong-un disguised an older missile as a new one to exaggerate his country’s weapons achievements when he badly needs political leverage.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showing what it said was a successful test launch of the Hwasong-17 at Pyongyang International Airport in North Korea on March 24.

item.title: Cheng Lei, Australian Journalist, Is Tried by China
item.description: Cheng Lei, a former CGTN host, was detained in 2020. The Chinese authorities have accused her of divulging state secrets but offered no specifics.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Before she was detained, Cheng Lei was a business news host for CGTN, China’s main international broadcaster.

item.title: What is the Wagner Group?
item.description: The private Russian military force, which has close ties to President Vladimir Putin and has been used in war zones across the world, is expanding its presence in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mercenaries from the Wagner Group in Bangui, Central African Republic, in 2019.

item.title: In Hong Kong, China’s Covid Aid Gets the Cold Shoulder
item.description: Disputes about medics, squat toilets and diaper-changing duties underscore longstanding tensions between residents of Hong Kong and the mainland.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: An isolation facility for people with Covid-19 being built on the site of a former airport runway in Hong Kong.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russian attacks on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers fortifying the Princess Olga monument in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia Steps Up Attacks Amid Reports of Rifts in Moscow
item.description: Despite claims of de-escalation, Russian forces turned their fury on Chernihiv and the suburbs of Kyiv. U.S. officials say they believe Vladimir Putin’s aides are misleading him about the war.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers using sandbags to fortify the Princess Olga Monument in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: President Dissolves Tunisia’s Parliament, Deepening Political Crisis
item.description: President Kais Saied, who suspended Parliament last year, dismissed that body after lawmakers challenged the autocratic powers he has exercised.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: President Kais Saied of Tunisia taking the oath of office in Tunis, in 2019.

item.title: Nigerians Mourn Victims of Deadly Train Attack
item.description: An attack by gunmen on a popular train route connecting Nigeria’s capital, Abuja, to a regional hub in the north, has left many with a growing feeling of insecurity.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ben Ezeamalu
item.media:description: The then newly completed Abuja-Kaduna night railway line in Abuja, Nigeria, in 2016.
